title: 111_hr5863
content: The Act is titled the "Oil Pollution Wildlife Protection Act" and includes a section on notice of exploration and development and production plans. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to include provisions for public notice of exploration and development plans. The Act also covers the Oil Pollution Wildlife Protection Act. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to require public notice of any applications or plans submitted to the Secretary, with exceptions for proprietary information. The Secretary must also publish notice of decisions to approve, deny, or modify plans. SEC. 3 amends Section 25 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to apply development and production plan requirements in the Gulf of Mexico. SEC. 4 ensures compliance with other laws. The Secretary must certify compliance with various environmental statutes before approving exploration plans or permits under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. The Secretary must certify compliance with environmental statutes before approving exploration plans or permits under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, including the Clean Water Act, Coastal Zone Management Act, and other relevant legal authorities. Prior consultation with federal agencies is required for certification. The Secretary must certify compliance with various environmental statutes before approving development and production plans under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, including the National Environmental Policy Act, Endangered Species Act, Marine Mammal Protection Act, Magnuson-Stevens Fisheries Conservation and Management Act, Clean Water Act, and Coastal Zone Management Act. Prior to certification, the Secretary must consult with relevant Federal agencies to ensure compliance with environmental statutes and regulations for activities under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. SEC. 5. CONSULTATION REQUIREMENTS FOR ENDANGERED SPECIES AND FISHERIES. Amendment to Section 19 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to include consultation requirements. The consultation requirements for endangered species and fisheries under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act include mandatory consultation with the Secretary of Commerce or Interior for listed species and with the Secretary of Commerce for fisheries conservation. SEC. 6 amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to consider cumulative impacts on marine mammal species and subsistence use when determining the impact of specified activities. SEC. 7 addresses citizen suits. Section 23 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to provide additional authority for civil actions against the United States or other agencies for approving certain activities without environmental impact assessments. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow civil actions against the United States for approving activities without environmental impact assessments, including consultation with relevant agencies under various statutes such as the Endangered Species Act and the Magnuson-Stevens Fisheries Conservation and Management Act. Additionally, the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 provides remedies for non-compliance with these statutes. Any person can take legal action to stop someone from engaging in activities that may harm marine mammals without proper authorization under the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972. This includes violations of any provision of the Act or related regulations. Under the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972, legal action can be taken to prevent unauthorized activities that may harm marine mammals. The Attorney General can intervene on behalf of the United States in such cases, and the court may award costs of litigation to any party as deemed appropriate. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to change the time frame for bringing legal action and the review process for leasing programs and plans. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to modify time frames for legal action and review processes for leasing programs and plans. The changes include adjustments to paragraph (3) and (5), increasing the time frame from sixty to ninety days, and specifying the parties involved in paragraph (1). Additionally, paragraph (6) is amended by removing a specific sentence. The nonrestriction clause ensures that individuals still have the right to seek enforcement under other statutes or common law.
